title: Non-uniform a - finding the position function

content.question: An object moves in one dimension along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the object is located at position <math alttext="x equals 1 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext> m</mtext></math> and has a velocity <math alttext="v equals 1 meter per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>. The object’s acceleration varies as <math alttext="a equals 3 t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> is in <math alttext="meter per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is time in seconds. A student incorrectly derives the equation for the object’s position as <math alttext="x equals one half times t cubed plus 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, where <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is in meters. Which of the following describes a possible error that could have resulted in the incorrect equation?

choices.label: The student’s equation does not account for the initial position of the object.
The student’s equation does not account for the initial velocity of the object.

The student’s equation does not substitute <math alttext="a equals 3 t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi></math> in the <math alttext="one half a, times t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> term.

The student’s equation should not have a <math alttext="positive 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded></math> term, as integrating the acceleration function twice yields <math alttext="x equals one half times t cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math>.

content.answer: The student’s equation does not account for the initial velocity of the object.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
